ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned Chinese characters and grammar structures.
I learned more Chinese grammar, characters, and pronunciation.
Improved vocabulary, grammar skills, speaking skills
During this class, I was able to develop better grammar, reading, and comprehension of Mandarin Chinese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Yale's Chinese department is very well-organized as a whole. Liu Laoshi, who was directing the umbrella course, gave very clear instructions. The weekly syllabus was easy to understand and the feedback on coursework was also very comprehensive. I definitely learned a lot. 

Weaknesses: I believe Guo Laoshi is a new professor so there were some days when we were not as engaged because we had already gone through all the textbook material, and were just reading off of the board. I think it could benefit from more social learning activities, such as Chinese Jeopardy, making example sentences in partner pairs rather than having to raise your hand and volunteer individually, and more collaborative activities in general.
The strength is the discipline the course requires. You learn a lot in the course of a semester. I think it could be improved to encourage more small discussions among classmates.
Strengths- well organized, great for heritage speakers, strong focus on writing characters
This class makes you memorize numerous amounts of characters, which is good since you will be able to read more Chinese. However, memorizing the textbook is a boring way to learn.

Strengths: Lots of individualized feedback

Weakness: Class became boring at times when we just read passages aloud

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I will always recommend taking Chinese, it is a rewarding language and a lot of fun especially in heritage tracks where you can meet other students of similar backgrounds.
Yes, this is a great intensive course to improve your Chinese.
Yes, especially if the student struggles with writing characters.
I would only recommend this course if you are willing to put in a lot of work and already have a solid background on Chinese grammar. This course is very time consuming and challenging.
